item.title: Chevron Plans 200 Job Cuts in the Permian Basin
item.description: Chevron Corp. plans to lay off 200 employees in the Permian Basin, less than the 800 previously reported by the Texas Workforce Commission, the company said Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Crowley

media:content.media:description: A Nabors Industries Ltd. roughneck uses a power washer to clean the drilling floor of a rig drilling for Chevron Corp. in the Permian Basin near Midland, Texas, U.S., on Thursday, March 1, 2018. Chevron, the world's third-largest publicly traded oil producer, is spending $3.3 billion this year in the Permian and an additional $1 billion in other shale basins. Its expansion will further bolster U.S. oil output, which already exceeds 10 million barrels a day, surpassing the record set in 1970.

item.title: Apollo Partners With Major US Banks to Trade Private Credit
item.description: Apollo Global Management Inc. is working with JPMorgan Chase & Co., Goldman Sachs Group Inc. and three other banks to trade private credit, partnering with Wall Street’s largest firms to syndicate investment-grade debt on a broader scale.
item.dc:creator: Laura Benitez, Todd Gillespie

media:content.media:description: The Apollo Global Management LLC office in New York.

item.title: Governor Andrew Bailey Speaks on Trade Wars
item.description: Bank of England Governor Andrew Bailey spoke on trade wars with Bloomberg's Francine Lacqua, at the Irish Association of Investment Managers Event in Dublin. He says there have been very big changes in core financial markets, shifting from a “bank dealer model” to a “non-bank model” and that the financial system has so far “stood up” to the changes. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Japanese Life Insurers Cut Bullish Yen Hedges to 14-Year Low
item.description: Japanese life insurers cut protection for their foreign assets against a stronger yen to a fresh 14-year low, signaling subdued expectations of a sustained rally in the nation’s currency.
item.dc:creator: Masaki Kondo, Hidenori Yamanaka

item.title: Investors are Suffering from Tariff Whiplash: David Kelly
item.description: Wall Street traders cheering solid results from Nvidia Corp. had to face the harsh reality of slowing economic data and legal uncertainties around Donald Trump’s trade war. The president told Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell he’s making a mistake for not cutting rates. The S&P 500 pared most of an advance that earlier approached 1%. A federal appeals court offered Trump a temporary reprieve from a ruling threatening to throw out the bulk of his tariff agenda. Treasuries rose on bets the Fed will slash rates twice this year and after a solid $44 billion sale of seven-year notes. The dollar fell. The US economy shrank at the start of the year, restrained by weaker consumer spending and an even bigger impact from trade than initially reported. Pending sales of previously owned homes last month fell by the most since September 2022, while a rise in recurring jobless claims signaled higher unemployment. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Daly Says Fed Policy, US Economy Are in a ‘Good Place’
item.description: Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco President Mary Daly says monetary policy is in a “good place” to continue to bring inflation down during a moderated conversation in Oakland, California.

item.title: Trump Pressed Powell to Lower Rates in White House Meeting
item.description: President Donald Trump pushed Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell to lower interest rates at their first in-person meeting since the president’s inauguration, the White House said.
item.dc:creator: Amara Omeokwe, Josh Wingrove

item.title: FHFA’s Pulte on Fed Rates, Future of Fannie and Freddie
item.description: Bill Pulte, head of the Federal Housing Finance Administration and chair of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, explains why he thinks the Federal Reserve should cut interest rates and discusses the future of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac on “Bloomberg The Close.”

item.title: Bailey Discusses Fours Points on State of Trade
item.description: Bank of England Governor Andrew Bailey spoke at the Irish Association of Investment Managers Event in Dublin. He shared four points on the current state of world trade saying “something has gone wrong” with the multilateral trade system and that the World Trade Organization cannot be abandoned. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Musk Departs DOGE Amid Business Empire Uncertainty
item.description: Elon Musk’s business empire faces an uncertain future as the Department of Government Efficiency leader steps back from government involvement. Bloomberg’s Michael Shepard discusses the development with Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow on "Bloomberg Technology." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Dell Beats on AI Boost | Closing Bell
item.description: Comprehensive cross-platform coverage of the U.S. market close on Bloomberg Television, Bloomberg Radio, and YouTube with Romaine Bostick, Alix Steel, Scarlet Fu, Carol Massar and Tim Stenovec. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Nvidia Beats Expectations Beyond Data Center Business
item.description: Nvidia’s networking and gaming revenue indicate the company is thriving beyond its data center and AI business, says Daniel Morgan, senior portfolio manager at Synovus. He joins Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow on "Bloomberg Technology." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Stocks Notch Modest Gains as Traders Weigh Tariff Reprieve
item.description: US stocks eked out a small gain Thursday as Wall Street assessed a deluge of headlines around the legal ramifications of President Donald Trump’s trade policies against an upbeat earnings readout from Nvidia Corp.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Semenova

item.title: See 'Constructive' Capital Markets: Shift4 Incoming CEO
item.description: Shift4 Payments incoming CEO Taylor Lauber speaks with Sonali Basak at the 10th Annual Goldman Sachs Leveraged Finance and Credit Conference. They discuss the health of the consumer, the trade war and capital markets. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Wildfires in Alberta Pose Growing Threat to Canada’s Oil
item.description: Wildfires are threatening about 5% of Canada’s crude output as a blaze in Alberta’s oil sands region spreads and approaches major production sites.
item.dc:creator: Robert Tuttle, Brian K Sullivan

item.title: S&P 500 Rally Fades on Tariff Angst as Bonds Climb: Markets Wrap
item.description: Wall Street traders cheering solid results from Nvidia Corp. had to face the harsh reality of slowing economic data and legal uncertainties around Donald Trump’s trade war. The president told Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell he’s making a mistake for not cutting rates.
item.dc:creator: Rita Nazareth

media:content.media:description: Cleo Capital Managing Director Sarah Kunst says Nvidia's Jensen Huang is the "best-suited CEO" to deal with the recent US-China trade tensions on "Bloomberg The Close." Nvidia said sales will be about $45 billion in the second fiscal quarter. That included the loss of roughly $8 billion in revenue from China because of export controls.

item.title: Dollar Drops on Renewed Trade Uncertainty, Soft Economic Data
item.description: Underwhelming US economic data weighed on the dollar on Thursday, amplifying investor uncertainty about the outlook for growth as a federal appeals court temporarily stayed a ruling that had blocked the Trump administration’s global tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Carter Johnson, Alice Gledhill, Ruth Carson

item.title: ECB’s Kazimir Found Guilty of Bribery and Plans to Keep Job
item.description: European Central Bank Governing Council member Peter Kazimir was convicted of bribery and fined €200,000 ($225,380) in a ruling that will cause embarrassment to the Frankfurt institution.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Hornak

item.title: Treasuries Rise as Auctions Highlight Solid Demand for US Debt
item.description: Investors snapped up US debt for a third straight day, helping to quell concern that a widespread “Sell America” sentiment would dampen the Treasury Department’s auction results.
item.dc:creator: Liz Capo McCormick, Sydney Maki

media:content.media:description: The US Treasury Department building in Washington, DC.

item.title: Apple Plans OS Rebrand, Its Biggest Ever
item.description: Apple is planning to rename its operating systems based on the release year rather than version numbers. Bloomberg’s Dana Wollman explains the reasoning behind the move in a conversation with Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow on "Bloomberg Technology." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Informatica CEO Weighs In on $8 Billion Salesforce Deal
item.description: Opportunities in generative AI drove the Salesforce-Informatica deal to completion, says Informatica CEO Amit Walia. He joins Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow on "Bloomberg Technology." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Nvidia Shrugs Off China Worries
item.description: JoAnne Feeney of Advisors Capital Management says Nvidia’s earnings show solid demand for the company’s chips, despite export restrictions costing $8 billion in Chinese revenue. Feeney joins Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow on "Bloomberg Technology." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Citi CEO Says US Economy Looks Stronger When Viewed From Europe
item.description: The US economic outlook remains stronger than Europe despite sweeping policy uncertainty causing ripples across the economy, according to Citigroup Inc. Chief Executive Officer Jane Fraser.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Surane, Todd Gillespie

item.title: Trump Tariff Ruling Temporarily Paused by Appeals Court
item.description: A federal appeals court temporarily paused a ruling against President Donald Trump’s global tariffs while weighing a longer lasting hold on the sweeping decision. Kailey Leinz reports on “Bloomberg The Close.”

item.title: NYC Fashion College to Be Acquired by Japanese Education Group
item.description: LIM College, a fashion-focused school in New York City, will be acquired by the Japan Educational Foundation, according to a Thursday release.
item.dc:creator: Maxwell Adler, Janet Lorin

media:content.media:description: Buildings in the Manhattan skyline in New York, U.S., on Thursday June 17, 2021. New York state's pandemic mandates were lifted last week, after 70% of the adult population has now been given at least one dose of a coronavirus vaccine. Photographer: Victor J. Blue/Bloomberg

item.title: Trade Court Ruling Extends Uncertainty: Matt Hornbach
item.description: US Treasuries rallied after a strong note auction and economic data revealed the economy shrank at the start of the year, reinforcing bets the Fed will lower rates twice by early 2026. Even as White House officials downplayed the implications of the court ruling that blocked President Trump’s sweeping levies, attention, quickly shifted toward the data. Morgan Stanley Global Head of Macro Strategy Matt Hornbach discusses on "Bloomberg Markets." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: US Importers Brace for Higher Shipping Costs
item.description: It has been two months since President Trump's Liberation Day when he announced tariffs on nearly every country on Earth, especially China. Since then, US retail businesses have reduced their shipments from China. Basic Fun CEO Jay Foreman explains how the tariffs have impacted the company on “Bloomberg Markets.” (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Corporate-Bond Sales Top $150 Billion in Busiest May Since 2020
item.description: The US investment-grade primary bond market is having its busiest May since 2020 as easing tariff pressure has spurred companies to borrow while they can, a trend that could continue next month.
item.dc:creator: Caleb Mutua

item.title: CFTC Awards Whistleblower $700,000 for Enforcement Tip
item.description: A whistleblower will receive roughly $700,000 for providing information about misconduct that prompted the US Commodity Futures Trading Commission to open an investigation and take action.
item.dc:creator: Nicola M White

media:content.media:description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission headquarters in Washington, DC.

item.title: QVC Bondholders Hire Centerview, Akin as TV Network Struggles
item.description: With a wall of debt facing QVC Group Inc., a group of bondholders has hired Centerview Partners as well as Akin Gump Strauss Hauer & Feld as advisers, according to people familiar with the situation.
item.dc:creator: Reshmi Basu
